docs.lead_paragraph: A study finds that cognitive behavioral therapy assists those who are both chronically tired and chronically sick.

headline.main: How an Insomnia Therapy Can Help With Other Illnesses

docs.snippet: A study finds that cognitive behavioral therapy assists those who are both chronically tired and chronically sick.

docs.lead_paragraph: The pharmacy retailer that stopped selling cigarettes last year is also expanding its in-store clinics, a business well suited to the quickly evolving health care landscape.

headline.main: How CVS Quit Smoking and Grew Into a Health Care Giant

docs.abstract: CVS' strong antismoking stance, which includes 2014 decision to stop selling cigarettes, is part of company's larger goal to transform itself from drugstore into major health care company, and abandoning tobacco allowed it to rebrand itself and make alliances with other health care providers; effort also reflects idea that there will be more profit in health and wellness than tobacco, but raises questions about other possibly unhealthy products CVS stocks on its drugstores' shelves.
docs.snippet: The pharmacy retailer that stopped selling cigarettes last year is also expanding its in-store clinics, a business well suited to the quickly evolving health care landscape.

docs.lead_paragraph: The bill could spur biomedical innovation, change how federal health officials approve drugs and increase funding for the National Institutes of Health.

headline.main: Bipartisan Partnership Produces a Health Bill That Passes the House
headline.print_headline: Bipartisan Partnership Produces a Health Bill That Passes the House

docs.abstract: Health care legislation written by Reps Fred Upton, Republican of Michigan, and Diana DeGette, Democrat of Colorado, passes easily; bill, which would update FDA approval process and increase funding to National Institutes of Health, would be funded by sale of oil from strategic petroleum reserve.
docs.snippet: The bill could spur biomedical innovation, change how federal health officials approve drugs and increase funding for the National Institutes of Health.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and SABRINA TAVERNISE

docs.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, a proposal for Medicare to cover end-of-life counseling touched off a political uproar that threatened to stall President Barack Obama's health care law in Congress. This week, when Medicare finally announced it would make the change, reaction was largely muted.

headline.main: Medicare's End-Of-Life Counseling Policy May Find Acceptance
headline.print_headline: Medicare's End-Of-Life Counseling Policy May Find Acceptance

docs.snippet: Six years ago, a proposal for Medicare to cover end-of-life counseling touched off a political uproar that threatened to stall President Barack Obama's health care law in Congress. This week, when Medicare finally announced it would make the change,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare said Wednesday it plans to pay doctors to counsel patients about end-of-life care, the same idea that sparked accusations of "death panels" and fanned a political furor around President Barack Obama's health care law six years ago.
docs.snippet: Medicare said Wednesday it plans to pay doctors to counsel patients about end-of-life care, the same idea that sparked accusations of "death panels" and fanned a political furor around President Barack Obama's health care law six years ago.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new analysis found out-of-pocket spending on the pill dropped by about half in the first six months of 2013 compared with a year earlier.

headline.main: After Health Care Act, Sharp Drop in Spending on Birth Control
headline.print_headline: Women Are Paying Less for Birth Control, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study published online in Health Affairs finds that passage of Affordable Care Act has resulted in women spending far less out-of-pocket for most birth control methods; estimates cost savings from birth control pill alone, most popular form of birth control, was around $1.4 billion in 2013.
docs.snippet: A new analysis found out-of-pocket spending on the pill dropped by about half in the first six months of 2013 compared with a year earlier.
